Description: The Department of Justice and 19 states and the District of Columbia entered into a $1.375 billion settlement agreement with the rating agency Standard & Poor's Financial Services LLC, along with its parent corporation McGraw Hill Financial Inc., to resolve allegations that S&P had engaged in a scheme to defraud investors in structured financial products known as Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities and Collateralized Debt Obligations.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Standard & Poor's Ratings Services would pay $58 million to resolve a series of alleged federal securities law violations involving fraudulent misconduct in its ratings of certain commercial mortgage-backed securities.

Description: Moody's Investors Service, Inc., Standard & Poor's, and Fitch, Inc. agreed to settlements that totalled approximately $900,000 in credits after the state alleged that they misrepresented the meaning of their public bond ratings and gave lower ratings to public bonds, resulting in increased costs of borrowing for the state, cities, towns and school districts. The announcement did not specify how much each company would provide in credits. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Standard & Poor's Financial Services LLC agreed to pay $687.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it inflated ratings of residential mortgage-backed securities and structured investment vehicle notes. This was part of a larger $1.375 billion settlement also involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-standard-and-poors-financial-services-

Company: Standard and Poor's Financial Services LLC
Description: Standard and Poor's agreed to pay $12 million to New York and $7 million to Massachusetts to resolve lawsuits alleging that it made false and misleading statements in its rating of certain Commercial Mortgage Backed Securities. The SEC was also part of the negotiation and received an additional $58 million; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-standard-and-poors-ratings-services

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced settled charges against S&P Dow Jones Indices LLC for failures relating to a previously undisclosed quality control feature of one of its volatility-related indices, which led S&P DJI to publish and disseminate stale index values during a period of unprecedented volatility.
